The origin of lace is disputed by historians, with claims from both Flanders and Northern Italy - two regions which were in close contact - dating it to the end of the 15th century. The practice spread throughout the Low Countries where it became a large part of the economy, with many centres such as Brussels, Mechlin, Valenciennes and Binche giving their name to the local style. Lace making was a woman's job and would be done at home, providing them with economic freedom. The hand-made product was so costly that in 1662, the English Parliament passed an act prohibiting the import of all foreign lace, as it was alarmed at how much money was being spent on it.

Lace is a delicate fabric made of yarn or thread in an open weblike pattern. There are many types of lace, classified by how they are made. A famous style is Brussels lace, a type of pillow lace, which was started to be produced in the 15th century and is well known for its delicacy and beauty. Originally it was only made from the finest spun linen thread, which was spun in dark damp rooms to keep the thread from becoming too brittle. Only one ray of light was allowed into the room, and it was arranged so that it fell upon the thread. Brussels lace was extremely expensive but nevertheless in high demand in England and France.
